descriptions.content:
Tibetan has no specific verb mood to express the conditional. The conditional is formed by adding the particle ན་ “if” to the verb in the subordinate clause or to its auxiliary. The particle ན་ is combined with auxiliaries in the case of ཡོད་ན་, འདུག་ན་, and ཡིན་ན་, but the following combinations are incorrect: *རེད་ན་ and *ཡོད་རེད་ན་.

The protasis (the “if” clause) may be preceded by the expression གལ་སྲིད་. There are basically three types of constructions, corresponding respectively to the present, past, and “future” conditional.

The present conditional expresses a possibility that has not occurred, but that remains a possibility at the time the statement is made; or else a pure hypothesis, about the likelihood of which the statement has nothing to say. In this case the verb in the subordinate clause appears in the past tense optionally followed by the past auxiliary པ་ཡིན་[1] and the main clause verb is in the future tense. The structure may be represented as follows:

  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (past) + ན་ […], Verb + Auxiliary (future)
  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (past) + པ་ཡིན་ན་ […], Verb + Auxiliary (future)

These constructions, which translate both the conditional and indicative moods of English, are by far the most commonly used in Tibetan to formulate conditionals. They are also sometimes used to express past and future conditionals.

  • བྱ་རིལ་ཚང་མ་བཟས་ན་གྲོད་ཁོག་ན་གི་རེད། “If he ate all the sweets, he would have a stomach ache.”
  • བྱི་རིལ་ཚང་མ་བཟས་པ་ཡིན་ན་གྲོད་ཁོག་ན་གི་རེད། “If he ate all the sweets, he would have a stomach ache.”
  • སྒམ་ལ་སྒོ་ལྕགས་བརྒྱབ་ན་ཅ་ལག་བརླག་གི་མ་རེད། “If you close the box with a padlock, the things won’t be lost.”
  • ཁྱེད་རང་གིས་མོ་ཊ་བཙོང་ན་ངས་ཉོ་གི་ཡིན། “If you were to sell your car, I’d buy it.”

On the other hand, the present conditional is often used to translate polite requests with the verb “can” or “may” (literally: would it be all right if…).

  • འདི་འདྲས་བྱས་ན་འགྲིག་གི་རེད་པས། “May I do that?”
  • ཁྱེད་རང་དོ་དགོངས་འདིར་གཟིམ་ན་འགྲིག་གི་རེད། “You can sleep here tonight.”

Finally, there is another construction involving the present conditional: The conditional subordinate is followed by the perfect auxiliary.

  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (past) + ཡོད་ན་ […], Verb + Auxiliary (future)

The meaning differs from the first two constructions only in terms of verb aspect:

  • བྱི་རིལ་ཚང་མ་བཟས་ཡོད་ན་གྲོད་ཁོག་ན་གི་རེད། “If he has eaten all the sweets, he will have a stomach ache.”

The past conditional expresses a possibility that could be envisaged in the past, but that did not actually occur. The verb in the subordinate clause is usually in the past tense-aspect (perfect or perfective); the main verb is usually in the past and is followed by the perfect auxiliary or auxiliaries of probability.[2]

  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (past) + ཡོད་ན་ […] Verb + ཡོད་རེད་ / པ་ཡོད་
  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (past) + པ་ཡིན་ན་ […] Verb + ཡོད་རེད་ / པ་ཡོད་

The following example demonstrates this:

  • བྱི་རིལ་ཚང་མ་བཟས་ཡོད་ན་གྲོད་ཁོག་ན་ཡོད་རེད། “If (he) had eaten all the sweets, he would have had a stomach ache.”

The perfective is also sometimes used:

  • བྱི་རིལ་ཚང་མ་བཟས་པ་ཡིན་ན་གྲོད་ཁོག་ན་ཡོད་རེད། idem.
  • སྒམ་ལ་སྒོ་ལྕགས་བརྒྱབ་ཡོད་ན་ཅ་ལག་བརླག་ཡོད་མ་རེད། “If the box had been padlocked, the things wouldn’t have been lost.”
  • Or: སྒམ་ལ་སྒོ་ལྕགས་བརྒྱབ་ཡོད་ན་ཅ་ལག་བརླག་པ་མེད། idem.
  • ཁྱེད་རང་གིས་མོ་ཏ་བཙོང་ཡོད་ན་ངས་ཉོས་ཡོད་རེད། “If you’d sold your car, I’d have bought it.”
  • Or: ཁྱེད་རང་གིས་མོ་ཏ་བཙོང་ཡོད་ན་ངས་ཉོས་པ་ཡོད།

The future conditional expresses a future possibility. In this case, the verbs of the subordinate and main clauses are in the future. This construction is not very commonly used, and it is usually replaced by the present conditional.

  • གལ་སྲིད་ […] Verb (present-future) + Auxiliary (future) + ན་ […] Verb + Auxiliary (future)
  • ཁྱེད་རང་གིས་མོ་ཊ་ཚོང་གི་ཡིན་ན་ངས་ཉོ་གི་ཡིན། “If you sell your car, I’ll buy it.” (Literally: If you will sell....)

 

[1] The auxiliary པ་ཡིན་ may be used with any verb class (volitional or non-volitional), although sometimes other auxiliaries such as བྱུང་ན་ or སོང་ན་ may also be used. There is a slight difference between the two constructions: when the verb is followed by the auxiliary པ་ཡིན་, it can indicate a mere hypothesis, a general statement that is not linked to the ongoing situation.

[2] See also the entry discussing the auxiliaries པ་ཡོད་ and པ་འདུག་. (xxlink MST 28.3.2.)
